Would you confirm that this isn't bug 34246, which happens only when running
with Eclipse's Ant support?  It seems unlikely that anything we do should affect
only Windows XP.
I confirm it.  This isn't the same bug. 

I am running ant.bat from the Ant distribution (Apache) under MS-DOS Console on 
Windows XP, not in Eclipse.  (In Eclipse, when I run the build.xml with Ant 
Support, I got the error reported on bug #34246)

Note also that I used different Java VMs (IBM 1.3.1) and Sun (1.4.2) SDK with
the same error.
Thanks for the confirmation.  I don't have an XP box.  Would you try this on the
command-line?  If it's there, it's a compiler issue; can you run with -verbose
and attach the log to the bug?  If not, then please run with ant -verbose and
setup the iajc task to run in verbose mode and attach the log.  Either way, we'd
like a verbose log, at least to check that there's nothing on the classpath on
that machine that interferes with the loading of our classes.  We're in the
run-up to 1.1.1, so your help really helps!

I'm still unable to reproduce this on NT using Ant 1.5.3 and Sun's 1.3.1 or
1.4.2, so I'm continuing to ask for more information.  I appreciate your help
and will ask the dev list for people to reproduce on their XP machines.

Here's what more I'm asking for (explanations below):
- in ant/bin/ant.bat, 
  - prefix "@echo off" on the first line with "rem "
  - insert "-verbose " before "org.apache.tools.ant.Main"

- run this, saving all output to a log, and attach the log to the bug

    ant -f build.xml > log.txt 2>&1

  (Attaching is better than adding to the comment because it makes the bug
readable.)

- if you have time, below I suggest some things you can investigate.

---- Explanations and investigation suggestions:
From your submitting an Ant trace, I conclude it does not occur on the command
line.  My theory (by analogy with the eclipse case) is that there's an
incompatible library on the classpath causing one of our classes to fail to
load, but which class or library is hidden by the way error-handling is done for
class loading.  I didn't see enough information in the Ant verbose trace to test
that theory.

One way to test is to fork the task as with the eclipse case.  The old ajc task
does not support forking, so I believe the way to do that is to change the
examples/build.xml Ajx target to replace the ajc invocation as follows:

from:
       <ajc destdir="${classes.dir}" argfile="${list}" 
          classpath="${aspectjrt.jar}"/>
to:
       <iajc destdir="${classes.dir}" argfile="${list}" 
          classpath="${aspectjrt.jar}"
          fork="on" forkclasspath="${aspectjtools.jar}"/>

If it runs fine when forked, then it is something with the classpath
(or with the ajc task).

I haven't looked recently and don't remember precisely, but the class loaders
for ant tasks might or might not delegate upwards first (as most class loaders
should).  If they do delegate upwards, then the incompatible library could be
anywhere on the Ant classpath: in the CLASSPATH variable, in ant's lib
directory, or in {jre}/lib/ext.  One way to find the explicit ant classpath is
to delete "@echo off" from the first line of ant/bin/ant.bat, run it, and then
scan for the line that invokes ant (org.apache.tools.ant.Main).  To find out
exactly which class is failing to load, add -verbose to the java options used
when invoking ant.  I'd be interested in seeing that and directory listings for
jre/lib/ext and ant/lib, esp. as compared to your Windows 2000 machine. 
(If/since it does not occur on the command-line, it's less likely to result from
differences in jre/lib/ext, though a variant delegation scheme could cause
this.) If you can, try the XP machine with the same contents of those
directories and a similar Ant classpath.  I really hope that there's some
difference between the setup of the XP and windows 2000 machines that explains
why this is failing on XP.
Good news!
I was able to run the build (ant all) with the following instructions you 
suggested by replacing the task ajc by iajc:

    <target name="Ajx" depends="init"
    ...
	  <iajc destdir="${classes.dir}" argfiles="${list}" verbose="on" 
		classpath="${aspectjrt.jar}"
			fork="on" forkclasspath="${aspectjtools.jar}"/>

    </target>

Howeverm if I remove those attributes in the iajc task
  fork="on" forkclasspath="${aspectjtools.jar}"
  
I still get the error.  So to run it without errors, I have to get thoses 
attributes in the iajc task (fork and forkclasspath)

Note also that the target "tracing-bc" does is not working because those
fork attributes are missing.

Hope this helps (I'm sur it is)

-Robert

You didn't insert "-verbose " before "org.apache.tools.ant.Main", so though I
can see your classpath, I can't see what class failed to load.  Knowing that, we
could look at the classes it requires to load, and look for those in your
classpath.  But we can also check this out directly.

This time, try unsetting the classpath:

  > cd doc\examples
  > set CLASSPATH=""
  > C:\apache-ant-1.5.3-1 -f build.xml

If it works, then the problem lies some library on your classpath.  We'd like to
know which one, so we could document it and see if there's anything we can do. 
Finding out which one would involve you retrying with binary subsets of your
classpath until you found which entry was invalid; that would be a great help. 
If you do using -verbose, it might give you a hint as to the culprit.  Thanks!


I found the problem. It's not related to AspectJ nor Eclipse, but a classpath
issue (Windows classpath in Environment variables) by installing WebSphere
Studio Enterprise Developer by IBM which use the eclipse Workbench as the core.

I have WebSphere Studio Enterprise Developer installed on my XP box and
this software updates the Windows CLASSPATH variable and the jar file
in conflict is eglbatchgen.jar (core jar file to generate J2EE stuff into
WebSphere Studio Enterprise Developer) which contains the conflit class
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.compiler.batch.Main.

So the problem is not a Windows XP one as I thaught originally, but a conflict
in the Windows CLASSPATH.

Maybe it would be wise to always fork those compiler process (ajc and iajc) ....
My 2 cents.

Thank's for the hints

-Robert
Thanks for the work.  (imho, Ant should not be using CLASSPATH because it causes
this kind of mistake.)

Resolving invalid (which is what we use for pilot/setup mistake of some sort). 
Users experiencing this bug should set their CLASSPATH to null before invoking ant.
